articles.headline: Madoff Expected to Plead Guilty Thursday
articles.snippet: A “plea proceeding” was cited in court filings as part of a proposal by federal prosecutors for allowing Bernard L. Madoff’s victims to be heard in court.
articles.abstract: A “plea proceeding” was cited in court filings as part of a proposal by federal prosecutors for allowing Bernard L. Madoff’s victims to be heard in court.
articles.lead_paragraph: Bernard L. Madoff is expected to plead guilty on Thursday to charges that he operated a worldwide $50 billion Ponzi scheme, according to court documents filed late Friday.

articles.headline: Savings Accounts for All: Simple, but Not Easy
articles.snippet: Automatic enrollment is a key factor in establishing near universal workplace savings accounts, but then it gets complex.
articles.abstract: Automatic enrollment is a key factor in establishing near universal workplace savings accounts, but then it gets complex.
articles.lead_paragraph: In his speech to a joint session of Congress late last month, President Obama said that we must begin a conversation about how to strengthen Social Security “while creating tax-free universal savings accounts for all Americans.”

articles.headline: Obama Reversing Stem Cell Limits Bush Imposed
articles.snippet: The president’s action, which will carry out a campaign pledge, involves a long-controversial intersection of science and personal moral beliefs.
articles.abstract: The president’s action, which will carry out a campaign pledge, involves a long-controversial intersection of science and personal moral beliefs.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  President Obama will announce Monday that he is reversing Bush administration limits on federal financing for embryonic stem cell research as part of a pledge to separate science and politics, White House officials said Friday.
articles.byline: By David Stout and Gardiner Harris

articles.headline: 6 Years In, Troops Glimpse Real Path Out of Iraq
articles.snippet: In many parts of Iraq, the contours of an American exit strategy have taken clearer shape than at any time before.
articles.abstract: In many parts of Iraq, the contours of an American exit strategy have taken clearer shape than at any time before.
articles.lead_paragraph: MAHMUDIYA, Iraq  As he returned to base here after a day patrolling a place once called the Triangle of Death, Capt. Landgrove T. Smith of the First Battalion, 63rd Armor, summarized the war in Iraq in a way that would once have been unthinkable.

articles.headline: Behind the Curtain at G.E.
articles.snippet: It’s been a bad week for General Electric, but investors started losing trust in the company nearly a year ago.
articles.abstract: It’s been a bad week for General Electric, but investors started losing trust in the company nearly a year ago.
articles.lead_paragraph: So this is what it has come to. General Electric appears to be in trouble.

articles.headline: For McCain, a Dual Role, Center Stage
articles.snippet: Senator John McCain, alternately his old coalition-building dealmaker and the gloves-off bruiser from the campaign, is rewriting the part of presidential loser.
articles.abstract: Senator John McCain, alternately his old coalition-building dealmaker and the gloves-off bruiser from the campaign, is rewriting the part of presidential loser.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  Senator John McCain is rewriting the part of presidential loser.

articles.headline: Under the Gun, Stores Struggle to Display Composure
articles.snippet: Some retailers have to present a calm face or risk provoking a panic that would send their companies spiraling into bankruptcy.
articles.abstract: Some retailers have to present a calm face or risk provoking a panic that would send their companies spiraling into bankruptcy.
articles.lead_paragraph: Amid the worst economic downturn of their careers, the chief executives of the nation’s retail chains face a dilemma.

articles.headline: Parents Sue Trustees Over Prep School’s Shutdown
articles.snippet: The parents claim the trustees, who also oversee a steel company, are acting out of self-interest.
articles.abstract: The parents claim the trustees, who also oversee a steel company, are acting out of self-interest.
articles.lead_paragraph: When the students of the Conserve School in Wisconsin poured into the auditorium on a blustery morning early this year, they had no inkling of what would follow.

articles.headline: Economic Crisis Takes a Toll on Flower Shows
articles.snippet: The New England Flower Show and others are gone this year, victims of the economic crisis and shifting demographics.
articles.abstract: The New England Flower Show and others are gone this year, victims of the economic crisis and shifting demographics.
articles.lead_paragraph: BOSTON  In March 1929, unaware that the start of the Great Depression was just months away, the Massachusetts Horticultural Society staged a flower show for its centennial with lavish abandon.

articles.headline: Obama Ponders Outreach to Elements of Taliban
articles.snippet: In an interview with The Times, President Obama opened the door to a reconciliation process in which the American military would reach out to elements of the Taliban.
articles.abstract: In an interview with The Times, President Obama opened the door to a reconciliation process in which the American military would reach out to elements of the Taliban.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  President Obama declared in an interview that the United States was not winning the war in Afghanistan and opened the door to a reconciliation process in which the American military would reach out to moderate elements of the Taliban, much as it did with Sunni militias in Iraq.
articles.byline: By Helene Cooper and Sheryl Gay Stolberg

articles.headline: The Last Days of the Oligarchs?
articles.snippet: The men who saw themselves at the Carnegies or Rockefellers of Russia may soon be thrown into the dustbin of history by the economic crisis.
articles.abstract: The men who saw themselves at the Carnegies or Rockefellers of Russia may soon be thrown into the dustbin of history by the economic crisis.
articles.lead_paragraph: MOSCOW

articles.headline: A.I.G., Where Taxpayers’ Dollars Go to Die
articles.snippet: Derivatives are a black hole at the big insurer, and the government keeps tossing in money.
articles.abstract: Derivatives are a black hole at the big insurer, and the government keeps tossing in money.
articles.lead_paragraph: “DERIVATIVES are dangerous.”

articles.headline: Pulling Art Sales Out of Thinning Air
articles.snippet: Larry Gagosian’s hard-charging art empire is facing new challenges in the downturn, but also opportunity.
articles.abstract: Larry Gagosian’s hard-charging art empire is facing new challenges in the downturn, but also opportunity.
articles.lead_paragraph: AT an opening at his Madison Avenue gallery a few weeks ago, Larry Gagosian wore a dark suit with a window-pane pattern and a look on his face that said, “Don’t ask.”

articles.headline: New Chairman Boos G.O.P. When He’s Not Cheerleading
articles.snippet: Republican moderates staked hopes of reform on Michael Steele, but does he have the discipline to execute a party makeover?
articles.abstract: Republican moderates staked hopes of reform on Michael Steele, but does he have the discipline to execute a party makeover?
articles.lead_paragraph: None of the guests seemed to be complaining, yet Michael Steele stood at a Fifth Avenue fund-raiser in New York on Wednesday evening and defended his month-old tenure as chairman of the Republican National Committee. His glasses had been askew since he pleaded his case on television that morning, and now he threw up his arms in admission.

articles.headline: Saudis Race All Night, Fueled by Boredom
articles.snippet: Drag racing may be the most popular sport of Saudi youth, an obsessive, semilegal competition.
articles.abstract: Drag racing may be the most popular sport of Saudi youth, an obsessive, semilegal competition.
articles.lead_paragraph: JIDDA, Saudi Arabia  The young men start gathering around midnight, on a broad strip of highway between the desert and the sea. By 1 a.m. there are hundreds of them, standing in clusters alongside their cars, glancing around uneasily for the police.

articles.headline: World Bank Says Global Economy Will Shrink in ’09
articles.snippet: In a bleaker assessment than those of most private forecasters, the World Bank predicted a shrinking of the global economy for the first time since World War II.
articles.abstract: In a bleaker assessment than those of most private forecasters, the World Bank predicted a shrinking of the global economy for the first time since World War II.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  In one of the bleakest assessments yet, economists at the World Bank predicted on Sunday that the global economy and the volume of global trade would both shrink this year for the first time since World War II.

articles.headline: Irish Assault Raises Specter of Brutal Days
articles.snippet: Politicians said the shootings Saturday had the earmarks of a bid by dissidents to destabilize the government.
articles.abstract: Politicians said the shootings Saturday had the earmarks of a bid by dissidents to destabilize the government.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON  After years of sharply reduced political violence in Northern Ireland, the gunning down of a group of British soldiers by suspected Irish Republican Army dissidents has shaken the Protestant and Catholic communities and challenged the still fragile cohesion of the province’s power-sharing government.

articles.headline: Geithner, With Few Aides, Is Scrambling
articles.snippet: Even as Timothy F. Geithner maintains a frenetic pace to help heal the economy, there are signs that events are getting ahead of him.
articles.abstract: Even as Timothy F. Geithner maintains a frenetic pace to help heal the economy, there are signs that events are getting ahead of him.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  Rarely have so few people had so little time to prop up so many pillars of the economy as those in the Treasury Department under Timothy F. Geithner.
articles.byline: By Edmund L. Andrews and Stephen Labaton

articles.headline: A Matrix of News Winners Buoys NBC
articles.snippet: The network has a strong claim to leadership, given its strength in news, cable television and its “Today” show in the morning.
articles.abstract: The network has a strong claim to leadership, given its strength in news, cable television and its “Today” show in the morning.
articles.lead_paragraph: NBC’s “Today” show has the longest winning streak in television history: every week for 13 years, and counting. Now the evening newscast competition seems to be swinging NBC’s way as well.

articles.headline: A Rising Dollar Lifts the U.S. but Adds to the Crisis Abroad
articles.snippet: As American investors and foreign central banks flock to safe investments like Treasury bills, poorer countries are having a harder time raising money.
articles.abstract: As American investors and foreign central banks flock to safe investments like Treasury bills, poorer countries are having a harder time raising money.
articles.lead_paragraph: As the world is seized with anxiety in the face of a spreading financial crisis, the one place having a considerably easier time attracting money is, perversely enough, the same place that started much of the trouble: the United States.

articles.headline: United, Newspapers May Stand
articles.snippet: It is time for newspapers to get together and figure out a new business model.
articles.abstract: It is time for newspapers to get together and figure out a new business model.
articles.lead_paragraph: Back when I was a young media reporter fueled by indignation and suspicion, I often pictured the dark overlords of the newspaper industry gathering at a secret location to collude over cigars and Cognac, deciding how to set prices and the news agenda at the same time.

articles.headline: Seeking Justice, Chinese Land in Secret Jails
articles.snippet: Rights advocates say leaders are using “black houses” to reduce the number of petitioners reaching Beijing.
articles.abstract: Rights advocates say leaders are using “black houses” to reduce the number of petitioners reaching Beijing.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIJING  They are often tucked away in the rough-and-tumble sections of the city’s south side, hidden beneath dingy hotels and guarded by men in dark coats. Known as “black houses,” they are unofficial jails for the pesky hordes of petitioners who flock to the capital seeking justice.

articles.headline: CNBC Thrives as Hosts Deliver News With Attitude
articles.snippet: At CNBC journalists have been encouraged to speak their minds, making the line between reporter and commentator almost indistinguishable at times.
articles.abstract: At CNBC journalists have been encouraged to speak their minds, making the line between reporter and commentator almost indistinguishable at times.
articles.lead_paragraph: Was last week the worst one in CNBC’s 20-year history — or the best?
articles.byline: By Brian Stelter and Tim Arango

articles.headline: President’s Political Protector Is Ever Close at Hand
articles.snippet: David Axelrod’s political advice carries more weight than most anyone else’s on President Obama’s payroll.
articles.abstract: David Axelrod’s political advice carries more weight than most anyone else’s on President Obama’s payroll.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  The pepperoni and cheese pizzas had been delivered, and a meeting about how to sell President Obama’s economic plan was set to begin  not at the White House, but a few blocks away in the seventh-floor apartment of David Axelrod.

articles.headline: Obama Is Leaving Some Stem Cell Issues to Congress
articles.snippet: While lifting restrictions on embryonic stem-cell research, President Obama is avoiding the question of whether tax dollars should be used to experiment on embryos themselves.
articles.abstract: While lifting restrictions on embryonic stem-cell research, President Obama is avoiding the question of whether tax dollars should be used to experiment on embryos themselves.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  While lifting the Bush administration’s restrictions on federally financed human embryonic stem cell research, President Obama intends to avoid the thorniest question in the debate: whether taxpayer dollars should be used to experiment on embryos themselves, two senior administration officials said Sunday.

articles.headline: Merck to Buy Schering-Plough for $41.1 Billion
articles.snippet: Merck, facing patent expirations, is hoping to shore up its research pipeline and expand its global reach.
articles.abstract: Merck, facing patent expirations, is hoping to shore up its research pipeline and expand its global reach.
articles.lead_paragraph: A drug deal that is mainly about the drugs.
